We're not saying that Congress acted in recognition of the standard under 1818(i) or 1818(e) at the point when it enacted 1821(k).
What we're saying is that when it enacted 1821(k), Justice Breyer, the courts, the majority, vast majority of courts at that time were already applying a uniform ordinary care standard.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: We, this Court had not.
This Court had not.

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: This Court had not, but Congress doesn't... it doesn't just enact laws in recognition of what this Court's decisions are.
Congress is presumed to know at least where there is a majority--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, but you just told us the opposite.

You just told us that the reason the... in response to Justice Ginsburg that the reason the first sentence makes sense even as applied to Federal institutions is that Congress didn't know what the law was.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It might be applying State law, they might be applying Federal law.
That's what you told Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: --Your Honor--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now in response to this question you say Congress must have assumed that they... you know, since the vast majority of lower courts were applying Federal law, that this was a Federal law at issue.

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: --Your Honor, there's no contradiction whatever.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay, well--

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: What we're saying is that Congress had no view as to what the correct answer was.
The vast majority of courts were applying Federal law, but some courts clearly were applying State law as well.
Congress had no reason, no desire to sort that out.
This was emergency legislation.
Congress said, whatever the courts are applying, they... you can continue to have that, but you're going to have gross negligence as a minimum, as a floor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Then how do you get a congressional policy for uniformity?
You've just said Congress took no position as to what was the correct law.

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If that's correct, how do you conclude in answer to Justice Breyer's question and other questions that somehow there is a congressional indication somewhere, (e), (i), or anyway, that there is a need for a uniform standard?

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: Your Honor, if that's gotten lost, I'm sorry.
The uniformity comes from HOLA itself, the Homeowners Loan Act.
As this Court interpreted the Homeowners Loan Act--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, that's Congress.

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: --What's that?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Oh, you're--

turn.speaker: richard_p_bress
turn.label: Mr. Richard P. Bress
turn.text: Right.
No, what I'm saying is, as this Court has interpreted the Homeowners Loan Act in de la questa, Congress intended at the time that statute was enacted to have uniform regulation of savings and loans.
Now, at the time FIRREA was enacted Congress wasn't interested in changing the workings of the internal affairs of banks themselves.
All it was saying was, when the FDIC comes in as receiver, in order to protect the insurance fund the FDIC is always going to be able to sue for gross negligence.
Now, it's still going to step into the shoes of the institution, but--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --You've answered the question, Mr. Bress.
Mr. Stevens, you have 2 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: ronald_w_stevens
turn.label: Mr. Ronald W. Stevens
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
The FDIC is saying, as a matter of policy we have to have uniformity.
That's its argument in this Court.

In FDIC v. Thall, a decision which came down in August of 1996 of this year from the Eleventh Circuit, the FDIC argued and prevailed exactly the opposite proposition, that State law should apply to federally chartered institutions.
They took the position in that case that the application of the internal affairs doctrine to federally chartered institutions was, and I quote from their brief, which is cited at--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Of course, they're entitled to change their position.
You've changed your position too, but--
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: ronald_w_stevens
turn.label: Mr. Ronald W. Stevens
turn.text: --We changed our position on the basis of a change in the law.
Theirs is a policy argument.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, but basically you do... you agree with Judge Posner's analysis, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: ronald_w_stevens
turn.label: Mr. Ronald W. Stevens
turn.text: No.
He uses an internal affairs... the internal affairs--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, he rejected that.

turn.speaker: ronald_w_stevens
turn.label: Mr. Ronald W. Stevens
turn.text: --doctrine.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, that--

turn.speaker: ronald_w_stevens
turn.label: Mr. Ronald W. Stevens
turn.text: Well, that's... he still used it, but he's... I believe... to the extent that he indicated it's not applicable, I agree with him.
The second point is that... that the OTS standard that they're talking about has nothing to do with simple negligence.
The... the... well, the... first of all, 1818(i) is a civil money penalty provision.
It's a provision for imposing a penalty, but the provision that deals with conduct precisely analogous to that at issue here is not a civil money penalty section.
It's not a fining section.

It's 1818(b)(6)(a), which is the section which gives the agencies to recover losses incurred by the institutions, Federal or State chartered, caused by directors and officers, and the standard for recovery there is not simple negligence.
Congress set the standard at unjust enrichment or reckless disregard.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --And what section are you referring to?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Stevens.
The case is submitted.
